headline: Walker's past could let Warnock keep Senate seat, rivals say
author: JEFF AMY
sentences: Walker's Republican rivals for U.S. Senate in Georgia are attacking him over reports by The Associated Press detailing police in Texas once confiscated a gun from Walker after a 2001 domestic disturbance, saying it adds to proof that Republicans risk losing the Senate race if they nominate Walker and leave him vulnerable to attacks.

I am the only candidate in this race who can lead us to victory against the Warnock-Abrams machine and stop Bidens destructive agenda, Saddler said in a statement, referring to current Democratic Sen. Raphael Warnock, presumed Democratic gubernatorial nominee Stacey Abrams and Democratic President Joe Biden.

(AP Photo/Ben Gray, File)
ATLANTA (AP)  Republicans risk losing the U.S. Senate race if they nominate Herschel Walker, two of Walker's rivals said, citing a report by The Associated Press about how police confiscated a gun from the former football great following a domestic dispute 20 years ago.

The AP reported Thursday that police in Irving, Texas, confiscated a gun from Walker in 2001 following a domestic disturbance because the former football legend talked about having a shoot-out with police.
Another rival, Navy veteran and former banker Latham Saddler said Thursday that Republicans need to nominate someone with a clean record and cant risk the drip, drip, drip of stories about Walker.

Im here today because more shocking pieces of Herschel Walkers past have been discovered, Senate candidate and state Agriculture Commissioner Gary Black told reporters Friday in Atlanta.
And Im deeply concerned that were about to forfeit control of the United States Senate again, under our watch, when it could be easily avoided.
Grossman in 2005 sought a protective order after Walker repeatedly voiced a desire to kill her and her boyfriend, according to court records.
Warnock and fellow Democrat Jon Ossoff won both Georgia Senate seats  and with them, the U.S. Senate majority  in January 2021.
She said Walker had violent outbursts and demonstrated physically abusive and threatening behavior.
Black repeated an earlier statement that Walkers past should disqualify him from the Senate.
Walker's ex-wife, Cindy Grossman, alleged that she was a repeated target of abuse.
Mallory Blount, a spokesperson for Walker, dismissed the report Thursday.
